thread.title: Baltimore councilman seeks increased penalties for motorists who park in bike lanes
thread.title_full: Baltimore councilman seeks increased penalties for motorists who park in bike lanes

author: Luke Broadwater
title: Baltimore councilman seeks increased penalties for motorists who park in bike lanes
text:
(Luke Broadwater and Yvonne Wenger) 
"It should be no different than me parking in the middle of the sidewalk or me parking in the middle of the street," Costello said. 
For years, advocates say Baltimore officials were slow to build protected bike lanes — which often means eliminating lanes for cars — even as they sprouted in Chicago, Indianapolis and New York. Portland, for instance, has 186 miles of bike lanes, including 11.5 miles of protected or buffered bike lanes. 
Baltimore officials are working to catch up. 
Costello said various federal, state and local agencies have spent more than $7 million on bike infrastructure in the city. Cyclist on Maryland Avenue A cyclist riding with traffic down Maryland Avenue A cyclist riding with traffic down Maryland Avenue (Lloyd Fox, Baltimore Sun) 
"If we're going to spend these types of capital dollars, then we need to be protecting it," he said. 
Liz Cornish, president of BikeMore, a local bicycling advocacy group, said motorists are using the bike lanes for unloading and loading zones. 
"The penalties for parking in a travel lane should be more consistent," she said. "If I were to stop my truck in the middle of Charles Street, get out and walk away, my truck wouldn't be there when I got back. 
"It's a safety issue. It's just not enough to put a ticket on the windshield. It can lead to crashes." 
A majority of the City Council has signed on as co-sponsors of Costello's bill, making it likely to pass. He is planning a hearing on the matter for March. 
Lester Davis, a spokesman for City Council President Bernard C. "Jack" Young , said Young backs the bill.
